intro: Brassica robertiana var. apenninica, commonly known as the Apennine mustard, is a herbaceous plant native to southern Europe. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and broccoli. The plant typically grows in rocky or disturbed soils and is characterized by its small, yellow flowers and elongated, hairy stems. It has lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface, and it produces small, elongated pods containing several seeds. This variety is often found in mountainous regions and is adapted to cooler climates.
